Abstract

We provide new and tight lower bounds on the ability of players to implement equilibria using cheap talk, that is, just allowing communication among the players. One of our main results is that, in general, it is impossible to implement three-player Nash equilibria in a bounded number of rounds. We also give the first rigorous connection between Byzantine agreement lower bounds and lower bounds on implementation. To this end we consider a number of variants of Byzantine agreement and introduce reduction arguments. We also give lower bounds on the running time of two player implementations. All our results extended to lower bounds on (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibria, a solution concept that tolerates deviations by coalitions of size up to kùëòk and deviations by up to tùë°t players with unknown utilities (who may be malicious).

1 Introduction

The question of whether a problem in a multiagent system that can be solved with a trusted mediator can be solved by just the agents in the system, without the mediator, has attracted a great deal of attention in both computer science (particularly in the cryptography community) and game theory. In cryptography, the focus on the problem has been on secure multiparty computation. Here it is assumed that each agent iùëñi has some private information xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}. Fix functions f1,‚Ä¶,fnsubscriptùëì1‚Ä¶subscriptùëìùëõf_{1},\ldots,f_{n}. The goal is have agent iùëñi learn fi‚Äã(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)subscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõf_{i}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}) without learning anything about xjsubscriptùë•ùëóx_{j} for j‚â†iùëóùëñj\neq i beyond what is revealed by the value of fi‚Äã(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)subscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõf_{i}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}). With a trusted mediator, this is trivial: each agent iùëñi just gives the mediator its private value xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}; the mediator then sends each agent iùëñi the value fi‚Äã(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)subscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõf_{i}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}). Work on multiparty computation (see [Gol04] for a survey) provides conditions under which this can be done. In game theory, the focus has been on whether an equilibrium in a game with a mediator can be implemented using what is called cheap talk‚Äîthat is, just by players communicating among themselves (see [Mye97] for a survey).

There is a great deal of overlap between the problems studied in computer science and game theory. But there are some significant differences. Perhaps the most significant difference is that, in the computer science literature, the interest has been in doing multiparty computation in the presence of possibly malicious adversaries, who do everything they can to subvert the computation. On the other hand, in the game theory literature, the assumption is that players have preference and seek to maximize their utility; thus, they will subvert the computation iff it is in their best interests to do so. Following [ADGH06], we consider here both rational adversaries, who try to maximize their utility, and possibly malicious adversaries (who can also be considered rational adversaries whose utilities we do not understand).

1.1 Our Results

In this paper we provide new and optimal lower bounds on the ability to implement mediators with cheap talk. Recall that a Nash equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma is a tuple of strategies such that given that all other players play their corresponding part of œÉùúé\sigma then the best response is also to play œÉùúé\sigma. Given a Nash equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma we say that a strategy profile œÅùúå\rho is a kùëòk-punishment strategy for œÉùúé\sigma if, when all but kùëòk players play their component of œÅùúå\rho, then no matter what the remaining kùëòk players do, their payoff is strictly less than what it is with œÉùúé\sigma. We now describe some highlights of our results in the two simplest settings: (1) where rational players cannot form coalitions and there are no malicious players (this gives us the solution concept of Nash equilibrium) and (2) where there is at most one malicious player. We describe our results in a more general setting in Section¬†1.2.

No bounded implementations:

In [ADGH06] it was shown that any Nash equilibrium with a mediator for three-player games with a 1-punishment strategy can be implemented using cheap talk. The expected running time of the implementation is constant. It is natural to ask if implementations with a bounded number of rounds exist for all three-player games. Theorem¬†2 shows this is not the case, implementations must have infinite executions and cannot be bounded for all three-player games. This lower bound highlights the importance of using randomization. An earlier attempt to provide a three-player cheap talk implementation [Ben03] uses a bounded implementation, and hence cannot work in general. The key insight of the lower bound is that when the implementation is bounded, then at some point the punishment strategy must become ineffective. The details turn out to be quite subtle. The only other lower bound that we are aware of that has the same flavor is the celebrated FLP result¬†[FLP85] for reaching agreement in asynchronous systems, which also shows that no bounded implementation exists. However, we use quite different proof techniques than FLP.

Byzantine Agreement and Game Theory:

We give the first rigorous connection between Byzantine agreement lower bounds and lower bounds on implementation. To get the lower bounds, we need to consider a number of variants of Byzantine agreement, some novel. The novel variants require new impossibility results. We have four results of this flavor:

  1. 1.

    Barany¬†[Bar92] gives an example to show that, in general, to implement an equilibrium with a mediator in a three-player game, it is necessary to have a 1-punishment strategy. Using the power of randomized Byzantine agreement lower bounds we strengthen his result and show in Theorem¬†4 that we cannot even get an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implementation in this setting.

  2. 2.

    Using the techniques of [BGW88] or [For90], it is easy to show that any four-player game Nash equilibrium with a mediator can be implemented using cheap talk even if no 1-punishment strategy exists. Moreover, these implementations are universal; they do not depend on the players‚Äô utilities. In Theorem¬†3 we prove that universal implementations do not exist in general for three-player games. Our proof uses a nontrivial reduction to the weak Byzantine agreement (WBA) problem¬†[Lam83]. To obtain our lower bound, we need to prove a new impossibility result for WBA, namely, that no protocol with a finite expected running time can solve WBA.

  3. 3.

    In [ADGH06] we show that for six-player games with a 2-punishment strategy, any Nash equilibrium can be implemented even in the presence of at most one malicious player. In Theorem¬†5 we show that for five players even œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì-implementation is impossible. The proof uses a variant of Byzantine agreement; this is related to the problem of broadcast with extended consistency introduced by Fitzi¬†et al.¬†[FHHW03]. Our reduction maps the rational player to a Byzantine process that is afraid of being detected and the malicious player to a standard Byzantine process.

  4. 4.

    In Theorem¬†8, we show that for four-player games with at most one malicious player, to implement the mediator, we must have a PKI setup in place, even if the players are all computationally bounded and even if we are willing to settle for œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äìimplementations. Our lower bound is based on a reduction to a novel relaxation of the Byzantine agreement problem.

Bounds on running time:

We provide bounds on the number of rounds needed to implement two-player games. In Theorem¬†9(a) we prove that the expected running time of any implementation of a two-player mediator equilibrium must depend on the utilities of the game, even if there is a 1-punishment strategy. This is in contrast to the three-player case, where the expected running time is constant. In Theorem¬†9(b) we prove that the expected running time of any œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äìimplementation of a two-player mediator equilibrium for which there is no 1-punishment strategy must depend on œµitalic-œµ\epsilon. Both results are obtained using a new two-player variant of the secret-sharing game. The only result that we are aware of that has a similar sprit is that of Boneh and Naor¬†[BN00], where it is shown that two-party protocols with ‚Äúbounded unfairness‚Äù of œµitalic-œµ\epsilon must have running time that depends on the value of œµitalic-œµ\epsilon. The implementations given by Urbano and Vila [UV02, UV04] in the two-player case are independent of the utilities; the above results show that their implementation cannot be correct in general.

1.2 Our results for implementing robust and resistent mediators

In [ADGH06] (ADGH from now on), we argued that it is important to consider deviations by both rational players, who have preferences and try to maximize them, and players that can be viewed as malicious, although it is perhaps better to think of them as rational players whose utilities are not known by the other players or mechanism designer. We considered equilibria that are (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust; roughly speaking, this means that the equilibrium tolerates deviations by up to kùëòk rational players, whose utilities are presumed known, and up to tùë°t players with unknown utilities (i.e., possibly malicious players). We showed how (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibria with mediators could be implemented using cheap talk, by first showing that, under appropriate assumptions, we could implement secret sharing in a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust way using cheap talk. These assumptions involve standard considerations in the game theory and distributed systems literature, specifically, (a) the relationship between kùëòk, tùë°t and nùëõn, the total number of players in the system; (b) whether players know the exact utilities of other players; (c) whether there are broadcast channels or just point-to-point channels; (d) whether cryptography is available; and (e) whether the game has a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy; that is, a strategy that, if used by all but at most k+tùëòùë°k+t players, guarantees that every player gets a worse outcome than they do with the equilibrium strategy. Here we provide a complete picture of when implementation is possible, providing lower bounds that match the known upper bounds (or improvements of them that we have obtained). The following is a high-level picture of the results. (The results discussed in Section¬†1.1 are special cases of the results stated below. Note that all the upper bounds mentioned here are either in ADGH, slight improvements of results in ADGH, or are known in the literature; see Section¬†3 for the details. The new results claimed in the current submission are the matching lower bounds.)

  • ‚Ä¢

    If o‚Äãn>3‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëúùëõ3ùëò3ùë°on>3k+3t, then mediators can be implemented using cheap talk; no punishment strategy is required, no knowledge of other agents‚Äô utilities is required, and the cheap-talk strategy has bounded running time that does not depend on the utilities (Theorem¬†1(a) in Section¬†3).

  • ‚Ä¢

    If n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ3ùëò3ùë°n\leq 3k+3t, then we cannot, in general, implement a mediator using cheap talk without knowledge of other agents‚Äô utilities (Theorem¬†3). Moreover, even if other agents‚Äô utilities are known, we cannot, in general, implement a mediator without having a punishment strategy (Theorem¬†4) nor with bounded running time (Theorem¬†2).

  • ‚Ä¢

    If n>2‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ2ùëò3ùë°n>2k+3t, then mediators can be implemented using cheap talk if there is a punishment strategy (and utilities are known) in finite expected running time that does not depend on the utilities (Theorem¬†1(b) in Section¬†3).

  • ‚Ä¢

    If n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ2ùëò3ùë°n\leq 2k+3t, then we cannot, in general, œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk, even if there is a punishment strategy and utilities are known (Theorem¬†5).

  • ‚Ä¢

    If n>2‚Äãk+2‚Äãtùëõ2ùëò2ùë°n>2k+2t and we can simulate broadcast then, for all œµitalic-œµ\epsilon, we can œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk, with bounded expected running time that does not depend on the utilities in the game or on œµitalic-œµ\epsilon (Theorem¬†1(c) in Section¬†3). (Intuitively, an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implementation is an implementation where a player can gain at most œµitalic-œµ\epsilon by deviating.)

  • ‚Ä¢

    If n‚â§2‚Äãk+2‚Äãtùëõ2ùëò2ùë°n\leq 2k+2t, we cannot, in general, œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk even if we have broadcast channels (Theorem¬†7). Moreover, even if we assume cryptography and broadcast channels, we cannot, in general, œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk with expected running time that does not depend on œµitalic-œµ\epsilon (Theorem¬†9(b)); even if there is a punishment strategy, then we still cannot, in general, œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk with expected running time independent of the utilities in the game (Theorem¬†9(a)).

  • ‚Ä¢

    If n>k+3‚Äãtùëõùëò3ùë°n>k+3t then, assuming cryptography, we can œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk; moreover, if there is a punishment strategy, the expected running time does not depend on œµitalic-œµ\epsilon (Theorem¬†1(e) in Section¬†3).

  • ‚Ä¢

    If n‚â§k+3‚Äãtùëõùëò3ùë°n\leq k+3t, then even assuming cryptography, we cannot, in general, œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk (Theorem¬†8).

  • ‚Ä¢

    If n>k+tùëõùëòùë°n>k+t, then assuming cryptography and that a PKI (Public Key Infrastructure) is in place,111We can replace the assumption of a PKI here and elsewhere by the assumption that there is a trusted preprocessing phase where players may broadcast. we can œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implement a mediator (Theorem¬†1(d) in Section¬†3); moreover, if there is a punishment strategy, the expected running time does not depend on œµitalic-œµ\epsilon (Theorem¬†1(e) in Section¬†3).

The lower bounds are existential results; they show that if certain conditions do not hold, then there exists an equilibrium that can be implemented by a mediator that cannot be implemented using cheap talk. There are other games where these conditions do not hold but we can nevertheless implement a mediator.

1.3 Related work

There has been a great deal of work on implementing mediators, both in computer science and game theory. The results above generalize a number of results that appear in the literature. We briefly discuss the most relevant work on implementing mediators here. Other work related to this paper is discussed where it is relevant.

In game theory, the study of implementing mediators using cheap talk goes back to Crawford and Sobel [CS82]. Barany [Bar92] shows that if n‚â•4ùëõ4n\geq 4, k=1ùëò1k=1, and t=0ùë°0t=0 (i.e., the setting for Nash equilibrium), a mediator can be implemented in a game where players do not have private information. Forges [For90] provides what she calls a universal mechanism for implementing mediators; essentially, when combining her results with those of Barany, we get the special case of Theorem¬†1(a) where k=1ùëò1k=1 and t=0ùë°0t=0. Ben-Porath [Ben03] considers implementing a mediator with cheap talk in the case that k=1ùëò1k=1 if n‚â•3ùëõ3n\geq 3 and there is a 1-punishment strategy. He seems to have been the first to consider punishment strategies (although his notion is different from ours: he requires that there be an equilibrium that is dominated by the equilibrium that we are trying to implement). Heller [Hel05] extends Ben-Porath‚Äôs result to allow arbitrary kùëòk. Theorem¬†1(b) generalizes Ben-Porath and Heller‚Äôs results. Although Theorem¬†1(b) shows that the statement of Ben-Porath‚Äôs result is correct, Ben-Porath‚Äôs implementation takes a bounded number of rounds; Theorem¬†2 shows it cannot be correct.222Although Heller‚Äôs implementation does not take a bounded number of rounds, it suffers from problems similar to those of Ben-Porath. Heller proves a matching lower bound; Theorem¬†5 generalizes Heller‚Äôs lower bound to the case that t>0ùë°0t>0. (This turns out to require a much more complicated game than that considered by Heller.) Urbano and Vila [UV02, UV04] use cryptography to deal with the case that n=2ùëõ2n=2 and k=1ùëò1k=1;333However, they make somewhat vague and nonstandard assumptions about the cryptographic tools they use. Theorem¬†1(e)) generalizes their result to arbitrary kùëòk and tùë°t. However, just as with Ben-Porath, Urbano and Vila‚Äôs implementation takes a bounded number of rounds; As we said in Section¬†1.1, Theorem¬†9(a) shows that it cannot be correct.

In the cryptography community, results on implementing mediators go back to 1982 (although this terminology was not used), in the context of (secure) multiparty computation. Since there are no utilities in this problem, the focus has been on essentially what we call here tùë°t-immunity: no group of tùë°t players can prevent the remaining players from learning the function value, nor can they learn the other players‚Äô private values. Results of Yao [Yao82] can be viewed as showing that if n=2ùëõ2n=2 and appropriate computational hardness assumptions are made, then, for all œµitalic-œµ\epsilon, we can obtain 111-immunity with probability greater than 1‚àíœµ1italic-œµ1-\epsilon if appropriate computational hardness assumptions hold. Goldreich, Micali, and Wigderson [GMW87] extend Yao‚Äôs result to the case that t>0ùë°0t>0 and n>tùëõùë°n>t. Ben-Or, Goldwasser, and Wigderson [BGW88] and Chaum, Cr√©peau, and Damgard [CCD88] show that, without computational hardness assumptions, we can get tùë°t-immunity if n>3‚Äãtùëõ3ùë°n>3t; moreover, the protocol of Ben-Or, Goldwasser, and Wigderson does not need an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon ‚Äúerror‚Äù term. Although they did not consider utilities, their protocol actually gives a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of a mediator using cheap talk if n>3‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ3ùëò3ùë°n>3k+3t; that is, they essentially prove Theorem¬†1(a). (Thus, although these results predate those of Barany and Forges, they are actually stronger.) Rabin and Ben-Or [RB89] provide a tùë°t-immune implementation of a mediator with ‚Äúerror‚Äù œµitalic-œµ\epsilon if broadcast can be simulated. Again, when we add utilities, their protocol actually gives an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation. Thus, they essentially prove Theorem¬†1(c). Dodis, Halevi, and Rabin [DHR00] seem to have been the first to apply cryptographic techniques to game-theoretic solution concepts; they consider the case that n=2ùëõ2n=2 and k=1ùëò1k=1 and there is no private information (in which case the equilibrium in the mediator game is a correlated equilibrium [Aum87]); their result is essentially that of Urbano and Vila [UV04] (although their protocol does not suffer form the problems of that of Urbano and Vila).

Halpern and Teague [HT04] were perhaps the first to consider the general problem of multiparty computation with rational players. In this setting, they essentially prove Theorem¬†1(d) for the case that t=0ùë°0t=0 and n‚â•3ùëõ3n\geq 3. However, their focus is on the solution concept of iterated deletion. They show that there is no Nash equilibrium for rational multiparty computation with rational agents that survives iterated deletion and give a protocol with finite expected running time that does survive iterated deletion. If n‚â§3‚Äã(k+t)ùëõ3ùëòùë°n\leq 3(k+t), it follows easily from Theorem¬†2: that there is no multiparty computation protocol that is a Nash equilibrium, we do not have to require that the protocol survive iterated deletion to get the result if n‚â§3‚Äã(k+t)ùëõ3ùëòùë°n\leq 3(k+t). Various generalizations of the Halpern and Teague results have been proved. We have already mentioned the work of ADGH. Lysanskaya and Triandopoulos [LT06] independently proved the special case of Theorem¬†1(c) where k=1ùëò1k=1 and t+1<n/2ùë°1ùëõ2t+1<n/2 (they also consider survival of iterated deletion); Gordon and Katz [GK06] independently proved a special case of Theorem¬†1(d) where k=1ùëò1k=1, t=0ùë°0t=0, and n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2.

In this paper we are interested in implementing equilibrium by using standard communication channels. An alternate option is to consider the possibility of simulating equilibrium by using much stronger primitives. Izmalkov, Micali, and Lepinski [IML05] show that, if there is a punishment strategy and we have available strong primitives that they call envelopes and ballot boxes, we can implement arbitrary mediators perfectly (without an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon error) in the case that k=1ùëò1k=1, in the sense that every equilibrium of the game with the mediator corresponds to an equilibrium of the cheap-talk game, and vice versa. In [LMPS04, LMS05], these primitives are also used to obtain implementation that is perfectly collusion proof in the model where, in the game with the mediator, coalitions cannot communicate. (By way of contrast, we allow coalitions to communicate.) Unfortunately, envelopes and ballot boxes cannot be implemented under standard computational and systems assumptions [LMS05].

It is reasonable to ask at this point whether mediators are of practical interest. After all, if three companies negotiate, they can just hire an arguably trusted mediator, say an auditing firm. The disadvantage of this approach in a setting like the internet, with constantly shifting alliances, there are always different groups that want to collaborate; a group may not have the time and flexibility of hiring a mediator, even assuming they can find one they trust. Another concern is that our results simply shift the role of what has to be trust elsewhere. It is certainly true that our results assume point-to-point communication that cannot be intercepted. If n‚â§k+3‚Äãtùëõùëò3ùë°n\leq k+3t, then we must also assume the existence of a public-key infrastructure. Thus, we have essentially shifted from trusting the mediator to trusting the PKI. In practice, individuals who want to collaborate may find point-to-point communication and a PKI more trustworthy than an intermediary, and easier to work with.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section¬†2, we review the relevant definitions. In Section¬†3, we briefly discuss the upper bounds, and compare them to the results of ADGH. In Section¬†4, we prove the lower bounds. The missing proofs appear in the appendix.

2 Definitions

In this section, we give detailed definitions of the main notions needed for our results. Sometimes there are subtle differences between our differences and those used in the game-theory literature. We discuss these differences carefully.

2.1 Mediators and cheap talk

We are interested in implementing mediators. Formally, this means we need to consider three games: an underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma, an extension ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} of ŒìŒì\Gamma with a mediator, and a cheap-talk extension ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} of ŒìŒì\Gamma. Our underlying games are (normal-form) Bayesian games. These are games of incomplete information, where players make only one move, and these moves are made simultaneously. The ‚Äúincomplete information‚Äù is captured by assuming that nature makes the first move and chooses for each player iùëñi a type in some set ùíØisubscriptùíØùëñ{\cal T}_{i}, according to some distribution that is commonly known. Formally, a Bayesian game ŒìŒì\Gamma is defined by a tuple (N,ùíØ,A,u,Œº)ùëÅùíØùê¥ùë¢ùúá(N,\mathcal{T},A,u,\mu), where NùëÅN is the set of players, ùíØ=√ói‚ààNùíØi{\cal T}=\times_{i\in N}{\cal T}_{i} is the set of possible types, Œºùúá\mu is the distribution on types, A=√ói‚ààNAiA=\times_{i\in N}A_{i} is the set of action profiles, and ui:ùíØ√óA:subscriptùë¢ùëñùíØùê¥u_{i}:{\cal T}\times A is the utility of player iùëñi as a function of the types prescribed by nature and the actions taken by all players.

A strategy for player iùëñi in a Bayesian game ŒìŒì\Gamma is a function from iùëñi‚Äôs type to an action in Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i}; in a game with a mediator, a strategy is a function from iùëñi‚Äôs type and message history to an action. We allow behavior strategies (i.e., randomized strategies); such a strategy gets an extra argument, which is a sequence of coin flips (intuitively, what a player does can depend on its type, the messages it has sent and received if we are considering games with mediators, and the outcome of some coin flips). We use lower-case Greek letters such as œÉùúé\sigma, œÑùúè\tau, and œÅùúå\rho to denote a strategy profile; œÉisubscriptùúéùëñ\sigma_{i} denotes the strategy of player iùëñi in strategy profile œÉùúé\sigma; if K‚äÜNùêæùëÅK\subseteq N, then œÉKsubscriptùúéùêæ\sigma_{K} denotes the strategies of the players in KùêæK and œÉ‚àíKsubscriptùúéùêæ\sigma_{-K} denotes the strategies of the players not in KùêæK. Given a strategy profile œÉùúé\sigma a player i‚ààNùëñùëÅi\in N and a type ti‚ààTisubscriptùë°ùëñsubscriptùëáùëñt_{i}\in T_{i} let ui‚Äã(ti,œÉ)subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùëñùúéu_{i}(t_{i},\sigma) be the expected utility of player iùëñi given that his type is tisubscriptùë°ùëñt_{i} and each player j‚ààNùëóùëÅj\in N is playing the strategy œÉjsubscriptùúéùëó\sigma_{j}.

Given an underlying Bayesian game ŒìŒì\Gamma as above, a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma is, informally, a game where players can communicate with the mediator and then perform an action from ŒìŒì\Gamma. The utility function of a player iùëñi in ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} is the same as that in ŒìŒì\Gamma; thus, the utility of a player iùëñi in ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} depends just on the types of all players and the actions taken by all players. Formally, we view both the mediator and the players as interacting Turing machines with access to an unbiased coin (which thus allows them to choose uniformly at random from a finite set of any size). The mediator and players interact for some (possibly unbounded) number of stages. A mediator is characterized by a function ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P} that maps the inputs it has received up to a stage (and possible some random bits) to an output for each player. Given an underlying Bayesian game ŒìŒì\Gamma where player iùëñi‚Äôs actions come from the set Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i} and a mediator dùëëd, the interaction with the mediator in ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} proceeds in stages, where each stage consists of three phases. In the first phase of a stage, each player iùëñi sends an input to dùëëd (player iùëñi can send the empty input, i.e., no input at all); in the second phase, dùëëd sends each player iùëñi an output according to ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}, (again, the mediator can send the empty output); and in the third phase, each player iùëñi chooses an action in Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i} or no action at all. A player can play at most one action from Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i} in each execution (play) of ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}. Player iùëñi‚Äôs utility function in ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} is the same as that in the underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma, and depends only on the action profile in Aùê¥A played by the players and the types. To make this precise, we need to define what move an action in Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i} is played by player iùëñi in executions of ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} where iùëñi in fact never plays an action in Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i}. For ease of exposition, we assume that for each player iùëñi, some default action ai‚àó‚ààAsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëñùê¥a_{i}^{*}\in A is chosen. There are other ways of dealing with this issue (see, for example, [AH03] for an alternative approach). Our results do not depend on the choice, since in our upper bounds, with probability 1, all players do play an action in equilibrium, and our impossibility results are independent of the action chosen if players do not choose an action. (We remark that the question of what happens after an infinite execution of the cheap-talk game becomes much more significant in asynchronous systems; see [ADH].)

Although we think of a cheap-talk game as a game where players can communicate with each other (using point-to-point communication and possibly broadcast), formally, it is a game with a special kind of mediator: player iùëñi send the mediator whatever messages it wants to send other players in the first phase of a round; the mediator forwards these messages to the intended recipients in the second phase. We can model broadcast messages by just having the mediator tag a message as a broadcast (and sending the same message to all the intended recipients, of course).

We assume that cheap talk games are always unbounded; players are allowed to talk forever. The running time of an execution of a joint strategy œÉùúé\sigma is the number of steps taken until the last player makes a move in the underlying game. The running time may be infinite.

It is standard in the game theory literature to view cheap talk as pre-play communication. Thus, although different plays of ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} may have different running times (possibly depending on random factors), it is assumed that it is commonly known when the cheap-talk phase ends; then all players make their decisions simultaneously. It is not possible for some players to continue communicating after some other players have decided (see, for example, [Hel05], where this assumption is explicit). For their possibility results, ADGH define games and give recommended strategies for these games such that, as long as players use the recommended strategy, all players make a move at the same time in each play of the cheap-talk game. However, it is not assumed that this is the case off the equilibrium path (that is, if players do not follow the recommended strategy). The assumption that all players stop communicating at the same time seems to us very strong, and not implementable in practice, so we do not make it here. (Dropping this assumption sometimes makes our impossibility results harder to prove; see the proof of Theorem¬†7 in Appendix¬†A.5 for an example.) Thus, there is essentially only one cheap-talk game extending an underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma,; ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} denotes the cheap-talk extension of ŒìŒì\Gamma.

When we consider a deviation by a coalition KùêæK, we want to allow the players in KùêæK to communicate with each other. If Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} is an extension of an underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma (including ŒìŒì\Gamma itself) and K‚äÜNùêæùëÅK\subseteq N, let Œì‚Ä≤+C‚ÄãT‚Äã(K)superscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùê∂ùëáùêæ\Gamma^{\prime}+CT(K) be the extension of ŒìŒì\Gamma where the mediator provides private cheap-talk channels for the players in KùêæK in addition to whatever communication there is in Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}. Note that Œìct+C‚ÄãT‚Äã(K)subscriptŒìctùê∂ùëáùêæ\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}+CT(K) is just ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}; players in KùêæK can already talk to each other in ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}.

2.2 Implementation

Note that a strategy profile‚Äîwhether it is in the underlying game, or in a game with a mediator extending the underlying game (including a cheap-talk game)‚Äîinduces a mapping from type profiles to distributions over action profiles. If Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} and Œì2subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{2} are extension of some underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma, then strategy œÉ1subscriptùúé1\sigma_{1} in Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} implements a strategy œÉ2subscriptùúé2\sigma_{2} in Œì2subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{2} if both œÉùúé\sigma and œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} induce the same function from types to distributions over actions. Note that although our informal discussion in the introduction talked about implementing mediators, the formal definitions (and our theorems) talk about implementing strategies. Our upper bounds show that, under appropriate assumptions, for every (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma in a game Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} with a mediator, there exists an equilibrium œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} in the cheap-talk game Œì2subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{2} corresponding to Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} that implements œÉùúé\sigma; the lower bounds in this paper show that, if these conditions are not met, there exists a game with a mediator and an equilibrium in that game that cannot be implemented in the cheap-talk game. Since our definition of games with a mediator also allow arbitrary communication among the agents, it can also be shown that every equilibrium in a cheap-talk game can be implemented in the mediator game: the players simply ignore the mediator and communicate with each other.

2.3 Solution concepts

We can now define the solution concepts relevant for this paper. In particular, we consider a number of variants of (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t) robustness, and the motivation behind them.

In defining these solution concepts, we need to consider the expected utility of s trategy profile conditional on players having certain types. We abuse notation and continue to use uisubscriptùë¢ùëñu_{i} for this, writing for example, ui‚Äã(tK,œÉ)subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæùúéu_{i}(t_{K},\sigma) to denote the expected utility to player iùëñi if the strategy profile œÉùúé\sigma is used, conditional on the players in KùêæK having the types tKsubscriptùë°ùêæt_{K}. Since the strategy œÉùúé\sigma here can come from the underlying game or some extension of it, the function uisubscriptùë¢ùëñu_{i} is rather badly overloaded. We sometimes include the relevant game as an argument to uisubscriptùë¢ùëñu_{i} to emphasize which game the strategy profile œÉùúé\sigma is taken from, writing, for example, ui‚Äã(tK,Œì‚Ä≤,œÉ)subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùúéu_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime},\sigma).

kùëòk-resilient equilibrium:

A strategy profile is a Nash equilibrium if no player can gain any advantage by using a different strategy, given that all the other players do not change their strategies. We want to define a notion of kùëòk-resilient equilibrium that generalizes Nash equilibrium, but allows a coalition of up to kùëòk players to change their strategies. One way of capturing this, which goes back to Aumann¬†[Aum59], is to require that there be no deviations that result in everyone in a group of size at most kùëòk doing better.

To make this intuition precise, we need some notation. Given a type space ùíØùíØ{\cal T}, a set KùêæK of players, and t‚ààùíØùë°ùíØt\in{\cal T}, let ùíØ‚Äã(tK)={t‚Ä≤:tK‚Ä≤=tK}ùíØsubscriptùë°ùêæconditional-setsuperscriptùë°‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë°‚Ä≤ùêæsubscriptùë°ùêæ{\cal T}(t_{K})=\{t\,^{\prime}:t\,^{\prime}_{K}=t_{K}\}. If ŒìŒì\Gamma is a game over type space ùíØùíØ{\cal T}, œÉùúé\sigma is a strategy profile in ŒìŒì\Gamma, and PrPr\Pr is the probability on the type space ùíØùíØ{\cal T}, let

ui‚Äã(tK,œÉ)=‚àët‚Ä≤‚ààùíØ‚Äã(tK)Pr‚Å°(t‚Ä≤‚à£ùíØ‚Äã(tK))‚Äãui‚Äã(t‚Ä≤,œÉ).subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæùúésubscriptsuperscriptùë°‚Ä≤ùíØsubscriptùë°ùêæPrconditionalsuperscriptùë°‚Ä≤ùíØsubscriptùë°ùêæsubscriptùë¢ùëñsuperscriptùë°‚Ä≤ùúéu_{i}(t_{K},\sigma)=\sum_{t\,^{\prime}\in{\cal T}(t_{K})}\Pr(t\,^{\prime}\mid{\cal T}(t_{K}))u_{i}(t^{\prime},\sigma).

Thus, ui‚Äã(tK,œÉ)subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæùúéu_{i}(t_{K},\sigma) is iùëñi‚Äôs expected payoff if everyone uses strategy œÉùúé\sigma and types are restricted to ùíØ‚Äã(tK)ùíØsubscriptùë°ùêæ{\cal T}(t_{K}).

Definition 1.

œÉùúé\sigma is a kùëòk-resilient‚Ä≤ equilibrium if, for all K‚äÜNùêæùëÅK\subseteq N and all types t‚ààùíØùë°ùíØt\in{\cal T}, it is not the case that there exists a strategy œÑùúè\tau such that ui‚Äã(tK,œÑK,œÉ‚àíK)>ui‚Äã(tK,œÉ)subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæsubscriptùúèùêæsubscriptùúéùêæsubscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæùúéu_{i}(t_{K},\tau_{K},\sigma_{-K})>u_{i}(t_{K},\sigma) for all i‚ààKùëñùêæi\in K.

Thus, œÉùúé\sigma is kùëòk-resilient‚Ä≤ if no subset KùêæK of at most kùëòk players can all do better by deviating, even if they share their type information (so that if the true type is tùë°t, the players in KùêæK know tKsubscriptùë°ùêæt_{K}). This is essentially Aumman‚Äôs¬†[Aum59] notion of resilience to coalitions, except that we place a bound on the size of coalitions.

As the prime suggests, this will not be exactly the definition we focus on. ADGH consider a stronger notion, which requires that there be no deviation where even one player does better.

Definition 2.

œÉùúé\sigma is a strongly kùëòk-resilient‚Ä≤ equilibrium if, for all K‚äÜNùêæùëÅK\subseteq N with |K|‚â§kùêæùëò|K|\leq k and all types t‚ààùíØùë°ùíØt\in{\cal T}, it is not the case that there exists a strategy œÑùúè\tau such that ui‚Äã(tK,œÑK,œÉ‚àíK)>ui‚Äã(tK,œÉ)subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæsubscriptùúèùêæsubscriptùúéùêæsubscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæùúéu_{i}(t_{K},\tau_{K},\sigma_{-K})>u_{i}(t_{K},\sigma) for some i‚ààKùëñùêæi\in K.

Both of these definitions have a weakness: they implicitly assume that the coalition members cannot communicate with each other beyond agreeing on what strategy to use. While, in general, there are equilibria in the cheap-talk game that are not available in the underlying game (so having more communication can increase the number of possible equilibria), perhaps surprisingly, allowing communication between coalition members can also prevent certain equilibria, as the following example shows.

Example 1.

Consider a game with four players. Players 1 and 2 have a type in {0,1}01\{0,1\}; the type of players 3 and 4 is 0. All tuples of types are equally likely. Players 3 and 4 can each choose an action in the set {0,1,punish,pass}01punishpass\{0,1,{\textsc{punish}},{\textsc{pass}}\}; players 1 and 2 each choose an action in {punish,pass}punishpass\{{\textsc{punish}},{\textsc{pass}}\}. If anyone plays punish,punish{\textsc{punish}}, then everyone gets a payoff of ‚àí11-1. If no one plays punish,punish{\textsc{punish}}, the payoffs are as follows: If player 3 plays pass, then 3 gets a payoff of 1; similarly, if player 4 plays pass, then 4 gets a payoff of 1. If player 3 plays 0 or 1 and this is 1‚Äôs type, then 3 gets 5; if not, then 3 gets -5; similarly for player 4. Finally, if player 2‚Äôs type is 00, then player 1 and 2‚Äôs payoffs are the same as player 333‚Äôs payoffs; similarly, if player 2 has a 1, then 1 and 2‚Äôs payoffs are the same as 4‚Äôs payoffs. It is easy to see that everyone playing pass is a 3-resilient‚Ä≤ equilibrium in the underlying game and it is also an equilibrium in the game with a mediator, if the players cannot communicate. However, if players can communicate for one round, then players 1, 2, and 3 can do better if player 1 sends player 3 his type, and player 3 plays it. This guarantees player 3 a payoff of 5, while players 1 and 2 get an expected payoff of 2.52.52.5.

Now suppose that we consider a variant of this game, where the actions are the same and the payoffs for players 3 and 4 are the same, but the payoffs for players 1 and 2 are modified as follows. If player 2‚Äôs type is 00, then if no one plays punish, player 1 and 2‚Äôs payoffs are the same as player 333‚Äôs payoffs if player 4 plays pass; if player 4 plays 0 or 1, then their payoff is ‚àí55-5. Similarly, if player 2‚Äôs type is 1, then player 1 and 2‚Äôs payoffs are the same player 444‚Äôs payoffs if player 3 plays pass; if player 3 plays 0 or 1, then their payoff is ‚àí55-5. It is easy to show that everyone playing pass is still 3-resilient‚Ä≤ if we allow only one round of communication. But with two rounds of communication, everyone playing pass is no longer 3-resilient‚Ä≤: players 1, 2, and 3 can do better if player 2 sends player 1 his type, player 1 sends player 3 his type if player 2‚Äôs type is 0 (and sends nothing otherwise), and player 3 plays player 1‚Äôs type if player 1 sends it. ‚äìsquare-intersection\sqcap‚äîsquare-union\sqcup

Since it seems reasonable to assume that coalition members will communicate, it seems unreasonable to call everyone playing pass 3-resilient if some communication among coalition members can destroy that equilibrium. More generally, we clearly cannot hope to implement a kùëòk-resilient equilibrium in the mediator game using cheap talk if the equilibrium does not survive once we allow communication among the coalition members. This motivates the following definition.

Definition 3.

œÉùúé\sigma is a (strongly) kùëòk-resilient equilibrium in a game Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} if, for all K‚äÜNùêæùëÅK\subseteq N with |K|‚â§kùêæùëò|K|\leq k and all types t‚ààùíØùë°ùíØt\in{\cal T}, it is not the case that there exists a strategy œÑùúè\tau such that ui‚Äã(tK,Œì‚Ä≤+C‚ÄãT‚Äã(K),œÑK,œÉ‚àíK)>ui‚Äã(tK,Œì‚Ä≤,œÉ)subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùê∂ùëáùêæsubscriptùúèùêæsubscriptùúéùêæsubscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùúéu_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime}+CT(K),\tau_{K},\sigma_{-K})>u_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime},\sigma) for some i‚ààKùëñùêæi\in K.

This definition makes precise the intuition that players in the coalition are allowed arbitrary communication among themselves.

Note that Nash equilibrium is equivalent to both 1-resilience and strong 1-resilience; however, the notions differ for k>1ùëò1k>1. It seems reasonable in many applications to bound the size of coalitions; it is hard to coordinate a large coalition! Of course, the appropriate bound on the size of the coalition may well depend on the utilities involved. Our interest in strong kùëòk-resilience was motivated by wanting to allow situations where one player effectively controls the coalition. This can happen in practice in a network if one player can ‚Äúhijack‚Äù a number of nodes in the network. It could also happen if one player can threaten others, or does so much better as a result of the deviation that he persuades other players to go along, perhaps by the promise of side payments. While it can be argued that, if there are side payments or threats, they should be modeled in the utilities of the game, it is sometimes more convenient to work directly with strong resilience. In this paper we consider both resilience and strong resilience, since the results on implementation obtained using the different notions are incomparable. Just because a strongly resilient strategy in a game with a mediator can be implemented by a strongly resilient strategy in a cheap-talk game, it does not follow that a resilient strategy with a mediator can be implemented by a resilient strategy in a cheap-talk game, or vice versa. However, as we show, we get the same lower bounds for both resilience and strong resilience: in our lower bounds, we give games with mediators with a strongly kùëòk-resilient equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma and show that there does not exist a cheap-talk game and a strategy that œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} that implements œÉùúé\sigma and is kùëòk-resilient. Similarly, we can show that we get the same upper bounds with both kùëòk-resilience and strong kùëòk-resilience.

Other notions of resilience to coalitions have been defined in the literature. For example, Bernheim, Peleg, and Whinston [BPW89] define a notion of coalition-proof Nash equilibrium that, roughly speaking, attempts to capture the intuition that œÉùúé\sigma is a coalition-proof equilibrium if there is no deviation that allows all players to do better. However, they argue that this is too strong a requirement, in that some deviations are not viable: they are not immune from further deviations. Thus, they give a rather complicated definition that tries to capture the intuition of a deviation that is immune from further deviations. This work is extended by Moreno and Wooders [MW96] to allow correlated strategies. Although it is beyond the scope of this paper to go through the definitions, it is easy to see that our impossibility results apply to them, because of the particular structure of the games we consider.

For some of our results we will be interested in strategies that give ‚Äúalmost‚Äù kùëòk-resilience, in the sense that no player in a coalition can do more than œµitalic-œµ\epsilon better by deviating, for some small œµitalic-œµ\epsilon.

Definition 4.

If œµ‚â•0italic-œµ0\epsilon\geq 0, then œÉùúé\sigma is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äìkùëòk-resilient equilibrium in a game Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} if, for all K‚äÜNùêæùëÅK\subseteq N with |K|‚â§kùêæùëò|K|\leq k and all types t‚ààùíØùë°ùíØt\in{\cal T}, it is not the case that there exists a strategy œÑùúè\tau such that ui‚Äã(tK,Œì‚Ä≤+C‚ÄãT‚Äã(K),œÑK,œÉ‚àíK)>ui‚Äã(tK,Œì‚Ä≤,œÉ)+œµsubscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùê∂ùëáùêæsubscriptùúèùêæsubscriptùúéùêæsubscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùúéitalic-œµu_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime}+CT(K),\tau_{K},\sigma_{-K})>u_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime},\sigma)+\epsilon for all i‚ààKùëñùêæi\in K.

Clearly if œµ=0italic-œµ0\epsilon=0, then an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äìkùëòk-resilient equilibrium is a kùëòk-resilient equilibrium.

(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium:

We now define the main solution concept used in this paper: (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium. The kùëòk indicates the size of coalition we are willing to tolerate, and the tùë°t indicates the number of players with unknown utilities. These tùë°t players are analogues of faulty players or adversaries in the distributed computing literature, but we can think of them as being perfectly rational. Since we do not know what actions these tùë°t players will perform, nor do we know their identities, we are interested in strategies for which the payoffs of the remaining players are immune to what the tùë°t players do.

Definition 5.

A strategy profile œÉùúé\sigma in a game ŒìŒì\Gamma is tùë°t-immune if, for all T‚äÜNùëáùëÅT\subseteq N with |T|‚â§tùëáùë°|T|\leq t, all strategy profiles œÑùúè\tau, all i‚àâTùëñùëái\notin T, and all types ti‚ààùíØisubscriptùë°ùëñsubscriptùíØùëñt_{i}\in{\cal T}_{i} that occur with positive probability, we have ui‚Äã(ti,Œì+C‚ÄãT‚Äã(T),œÉ‚àíT,œÑT)‚â•ui‚Äã(ti,Œì,œÉ)subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùëñŒìùê∂ùëáùëásubscriptùúéùëásubscriptùúèùëásubscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùëñŒìùúéu_{i}(t_{i},\Gamma+CT(T),\sigma_{-T},\tau_{T})\geq u_{i}(t_{i},\Gamma,\sigma).

Intuitively, œÉùúé\sigma is tùë°t-immune if there is nothing that players in a set TùëáT of size at most tùë°t can do to give the remaining players a worse payoff, even if the players in TùëáT can communicate.

Our notion of (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robustness requires both tùë°t-immunity and kùëòk-resilience. In fact, it requires kùëòk-resilience no matter what up to tùë°t players do. That is, we require that no matter what tùë°t players do, no subset of size at most kùëòk can all do better by deviating, even with the help of the tùë°t players, and even if all k+tùëòùë°k+t players share their type information.

Definition 6.

Given œµ‚â•0italic-œµ0\epsilon\geq 0, œÉùúé\sigma is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium in game ŒìŒì\Gamma if œÉùúé\sigma is tùë°t-immune and, for all K,T‚äÜNùêæùëáùëÅK,T\subseteq N such that |K|‚â§kùêæùëò|K|\leq k, |T|‚â§tùëáùë°|T|\leq t, and K‚à©T=‚àÖùêæùëáK\cap T=\emptyset, and all types tK‚à™T‚ààùíØK‚à™Tsubscriptùë°ùêæùëásubscriptùíØùêæùëát_{K\cup T}\in{\cal T}_{K\cup T} that occur with positive probability, it is not the case that there exists a strategy profile œÑùúè\tau such that

ui‚Äã(tK‚à™T,Œì+C‚ÄãT‚Äã(K‚à™T),œÑK‚à™T,œÉ‚àí(K‚à™T))>ui‚Äã(ti,Œì+C‚ÄãT‚Äã(T),œÑT,œÉ‚àíT)+œµsubscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæùëáŒìùê∂ùëáùêæùëásubscriptùúèùêæùëásubscriptùúéùêæùëásubscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùëñŒìùê∂ùëáùëásubscriptùúèùëásubscriptùúéùëáitalic-œµu_{i}(t_{K\cup T},\Gamma+CT(K\cup T),\tau_{K\cup T},\sigma_{-(K\cup T)})>u_{i}(t_{i},\Gamma+CT(T),\tau_{T},\sigma_{-T})+\epsilon

for all i‚ààKùëñùêæi\in K. A (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium is just a 0‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium.

We can define a strongly (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium by analogy to the definition strongly kùëòk-resilient equilibrium: we simply change ‚Äúfor all i‚ààKùëñùêæi\in K‚Äù in the definition of (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium to ‚Äúfor some i‚ààKùëñùêæi\in K‚Äù. Thus, in a strongly (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium, not even a single agent in KùêæK can do better if all the players in KùêæK deviate, even with the help of the players in TùëáT.

Note that a (1,0)10(1,0)-robust equilibrium is just a Nash equilibrium, and an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(1,0)10(1,0)-robust equilibrium is what has been called an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-Nash equilibrium in the literature. A (strongly) (k,0)ùëò0(k,0)-robust equilibrium is just a (strongly) kùëòk-resilient equilibrium. The notion (0,t)0ùë°(0,t)-robustness is somewhat in the spirit of Eliaz‚Äôs¬†[Eli02] notion of tùë°t fault-tolerant implementation. Both our notion of (0,t)0ùë°(0,t)-robustness and Eliaz‚Äôs notion of tùë°t-fault tolerance require that what the players not in TùëáT do is a best response to whatever the players in TùëáT do (given that all the players not in TùëáT follow the recommended strategy); however, Eliaz does not require an analogue of tùë°t-immunity.

In this paper, we are interested in the question of when a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma in a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator extending an underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma can be implemented by an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} in the cheap-talk extension ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} of ŒìŒì\Gamma. If this is the case, we say that œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma. (We sometimes say that (Œìct,œÉ‚Ä≤)subscriptŒìctsuperscriptùúé‚Ä≤(\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}},\sigma^{\prime}) is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of (Œìd,œÉ)subscriptŒìùëëùúé(\Gamma_{d},\sigma) if we wish to emphasize the games.)

3 The Possibility Results

All of our possibility results have the flavor ‚Äúif there is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium in a game with a mediator, then (under the appropriate assumptions) we can implement this equilibrium using cheap talk.‚Äù To state the results carefully, we must define the notions of a punishment strategy and a utility variant.

Definition 7.

If ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} is an extension of an underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma with a mediator dùëëd, a strategy profile œÅùúå\rho in ŒìŒì\Gamma is a kùëòk-punishment strategy with respect to a strategy profile œÉùúé\sigma in ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} if for all subsets K‚äÜNùêæùëÅK\subseteq N with |K|‚â§kùêæùëò|K|\leq k, all strategies œïitalic-œï\phi in Œì+C‚ÄãT‚Äã(K)Œìùê∂ùëáùêæ\Gamma+CT(K), all types tK‚ààTKsubscriptùë°ùêæsubscriptùëáùêæt_{K}\in T_{K}, and all players i‚ààKùëñùêæi\in K:

ui‚Äã(tK,Œìd,œÉ)>ui‚Äã(tK,Œì+C‚ÄãT‚Äã(K),œïK,œÅ‚àíK).subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæsubscriptŒìùëëùúésubscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùë°ùêæŒìùê∂ùëáùêæsubscriptitalic-œïùêæsubscriptùúåùêæu_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma_{d},\sigma)>u_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma+CT(K),\phi_{K},\rho_{-K}).

If the inequality holds with ‚â•\geq replacing >>, œÅùúå\rho is a weak kùëòk-punishment strategy with respect to œÉ.ùúé\sigma.

Intuitively, œÅùúå\rho is kùëòk-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma if, for any coalition KùêæK of at most kùëòk players, even if the players in KùêæK share their type information, as long as all players not in KùêæK use the punishment strategy in the underlying game, there is nothing that the players in KùêæK can do in the underlying game that will give them a better expected payoff than playing œÉùúé\sigma in ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}.

Notice that if k+t<n‚â§2‚Äãk+tùëòùë°ùëõ2ùëòùë°k+t<n\leq 2k+t, ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} is a mediator game extending ŒìŒì\Gamma, and œÉùúé\sigma is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium in ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}, then there cannot be a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma. For if œÉùúé\sigma is a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy, consider the strategy in the mediator game where a set TùëáT with |T|=t‚â•n‚àí(k+t)ùëáùë°ùëõùëòùë°|T|=t\geq n-(k+t) players do not send a message to the mediator, and just play œÅùúå\rho. If œÉùúé\sigma is tùë°t-immune, ui‚Äã(œÉN‚àíT,œÅT)‚â•ui‚Äã(œÉ)subscriptùë¢ùëñsubscriptùúéùëÅùëásubscriptùúåùëásubscriptùë¢ùëñùúéu_{i}(\sigma_{N-T},\rho_{T})\geq u_{i}(\sigma). But in the underlying game, if the players in N‚àíTùëÅùëáN-T share their types, they can compute what the mediator would have said, and thus can play œÉN‚àíTsubscriptùúéùëÅùëá\sigma_{N-T}, contradicting the assumption that œÉùúé\sigma is a punishment strategy.

The notion of utility variant is used to make precise that certain results do not depend on knowing the players‚Äô utilities; they hold independently of players‚Äô utilities in the game. A game Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma\,^{\prime} is a utility variant of a game ŒìŒì\Gamma if Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma\,^{\prime} and ŒìŒì\Gamma have the same game tree, but the utilities of the players may be different in ŒìŒì\Gamma and Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma\,^{\prime}. Note that if Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma\,^{\prime} is a utility variant of ŒìŒì\Gamma, then ŒìŒì\Gamma and Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma\,^{\prime} have the same set of strategies. We use the notation Œì‚Äã(u)Œìùë¢\Gamma(u) if we want to emphasize that uùë¢u is the utility function in game ŒìŒì\Gamma. We then take Œì‚Äã(u‚Ä≤)Œìsuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤\Gamma(u\hskip 1.42262pt^{\prime}) to be the utility variant of ŒìŒì\Gamma with utility functions u‚Ä≤superscriptùë¢‚Ä≤u\hskip 1.42262pt^{\prime}.

We say that broadcast can be simulated, if for all Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0, broadcast channels can be implemented with probability 1‚àíŒ¥1ùõø1-\delta. Broadcast can be simulated if, for example, there are broadcast channels; or if there is a trusted preprocessing phase where players may broadcast and assuming cryptography; or if unconditional pseudo-signatures are established [PW96].

In the theorem, we take ‚Äúassuming cryptography‚Äù to be a shorthand for the assumption that oblivious transfer [Rab, EGL85] can be implemented with probability 1‚àíœµ1italic-œµ1-\epsilon for any desired œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0. It is known that this assumption holds if enhanced trapdoor permutations exist, players are computationally bounded, and the mediator can be described by a polynomial-size circuit [Gol04].

Theorem 1.

Suppose that ŒìŒì\Gamma is Bayesian game with nùëõn players and utilities uùë¢u, dùëëd is a mediator that can be described by a circuit of depth cùëêc, and œÉùúé\sigma is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd.

  1. (a)

    If 3‚Äã(k+t)<n3ùëòùë°ùëõ3(k+t)<n, then there exists a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in Œìct‚Äã(u)subscriptŒìctùë¢\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}(u) such that for all utility variants Œì‚Äã(u‚Ä≤)Œìsuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤\Gamma(u^{\prime}), if œÉùúé\sigma is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium of Œìd‚Äã(u‚Ä≤)subscriptŒìùëësuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤\Gamma_{d}(u^{\prime}), then (Œìct‚Äã(u‚Ä≤),œÉct)subscriptŒìctsuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤subscriptùúéct(\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}(u^{\prime}),\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}) implements (Œìd‚Äã(u‚Ä≤),œÉ)subscriptŒìùëësuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤ùúé(\Gamma_{d}(u^{\prime}),\sigma). The running time of œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is O‚Äã(c)ùëÇùëêO(c).

  2. (b)

    If 2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt<n2ùëò3ùë°ùëõ2k+3t<n and there exists a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma, then there exists a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} such that œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} implements œÉùúé\sigma.     If 2‚Äã(k+t)<n2ùëòùë°ùëõ2(k+t)<n and broadcast channels can be simulated, then, for all œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, there exists a strategy œÉctœµsuperscriptsubscriptùúéctitalic-œµ\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}^{\epsilon} in ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} such that œÉctœµsuperscriptsubscriptùúéctitalic-œµ\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}^{\epsilon} œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implements œÉùúé\sigma.     If k+t<nùëòùë°ùëõk+t<n then, assuming cryptography and that a PKI is in place, there exists a strategy œÉctœµsuperscriptsubscriptùúéctitalic-œµ\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}^{\epsilon} in ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} such that œÉctœµsuperscriptsubscriptùúéctitalic-œµ\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}^{\epsilon} œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implements œÉùúé\sigma.     If k+3‚Äãt<nùëò3ùë°ùëõk+3t<n or if k+t<nùëòùë°ùëõk+t<n and a trusted PKI is in place, and there exists a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma, then, assuming cryptography, there exists a strategy œÉctœµsuperscriptsubscriptùúéctitalic-œµ\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}^{\epsilon} in ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} such that œÉctœµsuperscriptsubscriptùúéctitalic-œµ\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}^{\epsilon} œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implementers œÉùúé\sigma. Note that in part (a) we say ‚Äúthe running time‚Äù, while in the other parts we say ‚Äúthe expected running time‚Äù. Although all the strategies used are behavior strategies (and thus use randomization), in part (a), the running time is bounded, independent of the randomization. In the remaining parts, we cannot put an a priori bound on the running time; it depends on the random choices. As our lower bounds show, this must be the case.

We briefly comment on the differences between Theorem¬†1 and the corresponding Theorem 4 of ADGH. In ADGH, we were interested in finding strategies that were not only (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust, but also survived iterated deletion of weakly dominated strategies. Here, to simplify the exposition, we just focus on (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibria. For part (a), in ADGH, a behavioral strategy was used that had no upper bound on running time. This was done in order to obtain a strategy that survived iterated deletion. However, it is observed in ADGH that, without this concern, a strategy with a known upper bound can be used. As we observed in the introduction, part (a), as stated, actually follows from known results in multiparty computation [BGW88, CCD88]. Part (b) here is the same as in ADGH. In part (c), we assume here the ability to simulate broadcast; ADGH assumes cryptography. As we have observed, in the presence of cryptography, we can simulate broadcast, so the assumption here is weaker. In any case, as observed in the introduction, part (c) follows from known results [RB89]. Parts (d) and (e) are new, and will be proved in [ADGH07]. The proof uses ideas from [GMW87] on multiparty computation. For part (d), where there is no punishment strategy, ideas from [EGL85] on getting œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-fair protocols are also required. (An œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-fair protocols is one where if one player knows the mediator‚Äôs value with probability pùëùp, then other players know it with probability at least p‚àíœµùëùitalic-œµp-\epsilon.) Our proof of part (e) shows that if n>k+3‚Äãtùëõùëò3ùë°n>k+3t, then we can essentially set up a PKI on the fly. These results strengthen Theorem 4(d) in ADGH, where punishment was required and nùëõn was required to be greater than k+2‚Äãtùëò2ùë°k+2t.

4 The Impossibility Results

No bounded implementations

We prove that it is impossible to get an implementation with bounded running time in general if 2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò3ùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°2k+3t<n\leq 3k+3t. This is true even if there is a punishment strategy. This result is optimal. If 3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt<n3ùëò3ùë°ùëõ3k+3t<n, then there does exist a bounded implementation; if 2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò3ùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°2k+3t<n\leq 3k+3t there exists an unbounded implementation that has constant expected running time.

Theorem 2.

If 2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò3ùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°2k+3t<n\leq 3k+3t, there is a game ŒìŒì\Gamma and a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma such that there exists a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma for which there do not exist a natural number cùëêc and a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the cheap talk game extending ŒìŒì\Gamma such that the running time of œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} on the equilibrium path is at most cùëêc and œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma.

Proof.

We first assume that n=3ùëõ3n=3, k=1ùëò1k=1, and t=0ùë°0t=0. We consider a family of 3-player games Œì3n,k+tsuperscriptsubscriptŒì3ùëõùëòùë°\Gamma_{3}^{n,k+t}, where 2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò3ùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°2k+3t<n\leq 3k+3t, defined as follows. Byzantine Agreement and Game Theory

In [ADGH06] it is shown that if n>3‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ3ùëò3ùë°n>3k+3t, we can implement a mediator in a way that does not depend on utilities and does not need a punishment strategy. Using novel connections to randomized Byzantine agreement lower bounds, we show that neither of these properties hold in general if n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ3ùëò3ùë°n\leq 3k+3t.

We start by showing that we cannot handle all utilities variants if n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ3ùëò3ùë°n\leq 3k+3t. Our proof exposes a new connection between utility variants and the problem of Weak Byzantine Agreement¬†[Lam83]. Lamport¬†[Lam83] showed that there is no deterministic protocol with bounded running time for weak Byzantine agreement if t‚â•n/3ùë°ùëõ3t\geq n/3. We prove a stronger lower bound for any randomized protocol that only assumes that the running time has finite expectation.

Proposition 1.

If max‚Å°{2,k+t}<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëòùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°\max\{2,k+t\}<n\leq 3k+3t, all 2nsuperscript2ùëõ2^{n} input values are equally likely, and PùëÉP is a (possibly randomized) protocol with finite expected running time (that is, for all protocols P‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤P^{\prime\prime} and sets |T|‚â§k+tùëáùëòùë°|T|\leq k+t, the expected running time of processes PN‚àíTsubscriptùëÉùëÅùëáP_{N-T} given (PN‚àíT,PT‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)subscriptùëÉùëÅùëásubscriptsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùëá(P_{N-T},P^{\prime\prime}_{T}) is finite), then there exists a protocol P‚Ä≤superscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P^{\prime} and a set TùëáT of players with |T|‚â§k+tùëáùëòùë°|T|\leq k+t such that an execution of (PN‚àíT,PT‚Ä≤)subscriptùëÉùëÅùëásubscriptsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤ùëá(P_{N-T},P^{\prime}_{T}) is unsuccessful for the weak Byzantine agreement problem with nonzero probability.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†A.1. ‚àé

The idea of our impossibility result is to construct a game that captures weak Byzantine agreement. The challenge in the proof is that, while in the Byzantine agreement problem, nature chooses which processes are faulty, in the game, the players decide whether or not to behave in a faulty way. Thus, we must set up the incentives so that players gain by choosing to be faulty iff Byzantine agreement cannot be attained, while ensuring that a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust cheap-talk implementation of the mediator‚Äôs strategy in the game will solve Byzantine agreement.

Theorem 3.

If 2‚Äãk+2‚Äãt<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò2ùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°2k+2t<n\leq 3k+3t, there is a game Œì‚Äã(u)Œìùë¢\Gamma(u) and a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma such that there exists a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma and there does not exist a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} such that for all utility variants Œì‚Äã(u‚Ä≤)Œìsuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤\Gamma(u\hskip 1.42262pt^{\prime}) of Œì‚Äã(u)Œìùë¢\Gamma(u), if œÉùúé\sigma is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium of Œìd‚Äã(u‚Ä≤)subscriptŒìùëësuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤\Gamma_{d}(u\hskip 1.42262pt^{\prime}), then (Œìct‚Äã(u‚Ä≤),œÉct)subscriptŒìctsuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤subscriptùúéct(\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}(u\hskip 1.42262pt^{\prime}),\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}) is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of (Œìd‚Äã(u‚Ä≤),œÉ)subscriptŒìùëësuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤ùúé(\Gamma_{d}(u\hskip 1.42262pt^{\prime}),\sigma).

See Appendix¬†A.1. ‚àé

Theorem¬†3 shows that we cannot, in general, get a uniform implementation if n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ3ùëò3ùë°n\leq 3k+3t. As shown in Theorem¬†1(b)‚Äì(e), we can implement mediators if n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ3ùëò3ùë°n\leq 3k+3t by taking advantage of knowing the players‚Äô utilities.

We next prove that if 2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò3ùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°2k+3t<n\leq 3k+3t, although mediators can be implemented, they cannot be implemented without a punishment strategy. In fact we prove that they cannot even be œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äìimplemented without a punishment strategy. Barany¬†[Bar92] proves a weaker version of a special case of this result, where n=3ùëõ3n=3, k=1ùëò1k=1, and t=0ùë°0t=0.It is not clear how to extend Barany‚Äôs argument to the general case, or to œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äìimplementation. We use the power of randomized Byzantine agreement lower bounds for this result.

Theorem 4.

If 2‚Äãk+2‚Äãt<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò2ùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°2k+2t<n\leq 3k+3t, then there exists a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, an œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, and a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma, for which there does not exist a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT game that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma such that œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†A.2. ‚àé

We now show that the assumption that n>2‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ2ùëò3ùë°n>2k+3t in Theorem¬†1 is necessary. More precisely, we show that if n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ2ùëò3ùë°n\leq 2k+3t, then there is a game with a mediator that has a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium that does not have a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation in a cheap-talk game. We actually prove a stronger result: we show that there cannot even be an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation, for sufficiently small œµitalic-œµ\epsilon.

Theorem 5.

If k+2‚Äãt<n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëò2ùë°ùëõ2ùëò3ùë°k+2t<n\leq 2k+3t, there exists a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma, a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma, and an œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, such that there does not exist a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT extension of ŒìŒì\Gamma such that œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma.

The proof of Theorem¬†5 splits into two cases: (1) 2‚Äãk+2‚Äãt<n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò2ùë°ùëõ2ùëò3ùë°2k+2t<n\leq 2k+3t and t‚â•1ùë°1t\geq 1 and (2) k+2‚Äãt<n‚â§2‚Äãk+2‚Äãtùëò2ùë°ùëõ2ùëò2ùë°k+2t<n\leq 2k+2t. For the first case, we use a reduction to a generalization of the Byzantine agreement problem called the (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-Detect/Agree¬†problem. This problem is closely related to the problem of broadcast with extended consistency introduced by Fitzi¬†et al.¬†[FHHW03].

Theorem 6.

If 2‚Äãk+2‚Äãt<n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò2ùë°ùëõ2ùëò3ùë°2k+2t<n\leq 2k+3t and t‚â•1ùë°1t\geq 1, there exists a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, an œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma, and a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma, such that there does not exist a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT extension of ŒìŒì\Gamma which is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†A.4. ‚àé

We then consider the second case of Theorem¬†5, where k+2‚Äãt<n‚â§2‚Äãk+2‚Äãtùëò2ùë°ùëõ2ùëò2ùë°k+2t<n\leq 2k+2t. Since we do not assume players know when other players have decided in the underlying game, our proof is a strengthening of the lower bounds of [SRA81, Hel05].

Theorem 7.

If k+2‚Äãt<n‚â§2‚Äãk+2‚Äãtùëò2ùë°ùëõ2ùëò2ùë°k+2t<n\leq 2k+2t, there exist a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, an œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, a mediator game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} extending ŒìŒì\Gamma, a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}, and a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy œÅùúå\rho with respect to œÉ,ùúé\sigma, such that there is no strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} that is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma in the cheap-talk extension of ŒìŒì\Gamma, even with broadcast channels.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†A.5. ‚àé

Our last lower bound using Byzantine agrement impossibilities gives tight bounds to the result of Theorem¬†1(e) for the case that n>k+3‚Äãtùëõùëò3ùë°n>k+3t. We show that a PKI cannot be set up on the fly if n‚â§k+3‚Äãtùëõùëò3ùë°n\leq k+3t. Our proof is based on a reduction to a lower bound for the (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-partial broadcast problem, a novel variant of Byzantine agreement that can be viewed as capturing minimal conditions that still allow us to prove strong randomized lower bounds.

Theorem 8.

If max‚Å°(2,k+t)<n‚â§k+3‚Äãt2ùëòùë°ùëõùëò3ùë°\max(2,k+t)<n\leq k+3t, then there is a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma for which there does not exist a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT game that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma such that œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma even if players are computationally bounded and we assume cryptography.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†A.6. ‚àé

Tight bounds on running time

We now turn our attention to running times. We provide tight bounds on the number of rounds needed to œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äìimplement equilibrium when k+t<n‚â§2‚Äã(k+t)ùëòùë°ùëõ2ùëòùë°k+t<n\leq 2(k+t). When 2‚Äã(k+t)<n2ùëòùë°ùëõ2(k+t)<n then the expected running time is independent of the game utilities and independent of œµitalic-œµ\epsilon. We show that for k+t<n‚â§2‚Äã(k+t)ùëòùë°ùëõ2ùëòùë°k+t<n\leq 2(k+t) this is not the case. The expected running time must depend on the utilities, and if punishment does not exist then the running time must also depend on œµitalic-œµ\epsilon.

Theorem 9.

If k+t<n‚â§2‚Äã(k+t)ùëòùë°ùëõ2ùëòùë°k+t<n\leq 2(k+t) and k‚â•1ùëò1k\geq 1, then there exists a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, a mediator game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma, a strategy œÉùúé\sigma in ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}, and a strategy œÅùúå\rho in ŒìŒì\Gamma such that

  • (a)

    for all œµitalic-œµ\epsilon and bùëèb, there exists a utility function ub,œµsuperscriptùë¢ùëèitalic-œµu^{\,b,\epsilon} such that œÉùúé\sigma is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium in Œìd‚Äã(ub,œµ)subscriptŒìùëësuperscriptùë¢ùëèitalic-œµ\Gamma_{d}(u^{\,b,\epsilon}) for all bùëèb and œµitalic-œµ\epsilon, œÅùúå\rho is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma in Œì‚Äã(ub,œµ)Œìsuperscriptùë¢ùëèitalic-œµ\Gamma(u^{\,b,\epsilon}) if n>k+2‚Äãtùëõùëò2ùë°n>k+2t, and there does not exist an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma that runs in expected time bùëèb in the cheap-talk extension Œìct‚Äã(ub,œµ)subscriptŒìctsuperscriptùë¢ùëèitalic-œµ\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}(u^{b,\epsilon}) of Œì‚Äã(ub,œµ)Œìsuperscriptùë¢ùëèitalic-œµ\Gamma(u^{b,\epsilon});

  • (b)

    there exists a utility function uùë¢u such that œÉùúé\sigma is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium in Œìd‚Äã(u)subscriptŒìùëëùë¢\Gamma_{d}(u) and, for all bùëèb, there exists œµitalic-œµ\epsilon such that there does not exist an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉisuperscriptùúéùëñ\sigma^{i} that runs in expected time bùëèb in the cheap-talk extension Œìct‚Äã(u)subscriptŒìctùë¢\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}(u) of Œì‚Äã(u)Œìùë¢\Gamma(u).

This is true even if players are computationally bounded, we assume cryptography and there are broadcast channels.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†A.7. ‚àé

Note that, in part (b), it is not assumed that there is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma in Œì‚Äã(u)Œìùë¢\Gamma(u). With a punishment strategy, for a fixed family of utility functions, we can implement an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust strategy in the mediator game using cheap talk with running time that is independent of œµitalic-œµ\epsilon; with no punishment strategy, the running time depends on œµitalic-œµ\epsilon in general.

5 Conclusions

We have provided conditions under which a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium with a mediator can be implemented using cheap talk, and proved essentially matching lower bounds. There are still a few gaps in our theorems, as well as other related issues to explore. We list some of them here.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In Theorem¬†1(c), we get only an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-implementation for some œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0. Can we take œµ=0italic-œµ0\epsilon=0 here?

  • ‚Ä¢

    We require that the cheap-talk implementation be only a Nash equilibrium. But when we use a punishment strategy, this may require a player to do something that results in him being much worse off (although in equilibrium this will never occur, since if everyone follows the recommended strategy, there will never be a need for punishment). It may be more reasonable to require that the cheap-talk implementation be a sequential equilibrium [KW82] where, intuitively, a player is making a best response even off the equilibrium path. To ensure that the cheap-talk strategy is a sequential equilibrium, Ben-Porath [Ben03] requires that the punishment strategy itself be a Nash equilibrium. We believe for our results where a punishment strategy is not required, the cheap-talk strategy is in fact a sequential equilibrium and, in the cases where a punishment strategy is required, if we assume that the punishment strategy is a Nash equilibrium, then the cheap-talk strategy will be a sequential equilibrium. However, we have not checked this carefully. It would also be interesting to consider the extent to which the cheap-talk strategy satisfies other refinements of Nash equilibrium, such as perfect equilibrium [Sel75].

  • ‚Ä¢

    Our focus in this paper has been the synchronous case. We are currently exploring the asynchronous case. While we had originally assumed that implementation would not be possible in the asynchronous case, it now seems that many of the ideas of our possibility results carry over to the asynchronous case. However, a number of new issues arise. In particular, we need to be careful in dealing with uncertainty. The traditional assumption in game theory is to quantify all uncertainty probabilistically. But with asynchrony, part of the uncertainty involves, how long it will take a message to arrive and when agents will be scheduled to move. (In general, in an asynchronous setting, one player can make many moves before a second agent makes a single move.) It is far from clear what an appropriate distribution would be to characterize this uncertainty. Thus, the tradition in distributed computing has been to assume that an adversary decides message delivery time and when agents are scheduled. The results in the asynchronous case depend on how we deal with the uncertainty, which in turn affects the notion of equilibrium.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We have assumed that in the cheap-talk game, every player can talk directly to every other player. It would be interesting to examine what happens if there is a communication network which characterizes which players a given player can talk to directly.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In the definition of tùë°t-immunity and (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robustness, we have allowed the players in TùëáT to use arbitrary strategies. In practice, we may be interested only in restricting each player iùëñi in TùëáT to using a strategy in some predetermined set Si‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëñ‚Ä≤S_{i}^{\prime}.

We hope to return to all these issues in future work.

Appendix

Appendix A Proofs

This section includes the proofs for all results stated in the main text. We repeat the statement of the results for the readers‚Äô convenience.

A.1 Proof of Theorem¬†3

In the weak Byzantine agreement problem, there are nùëõn processes, up to tùë°t of which may be faulty (‚ÄúByzantine‚Äù). Each process has some initial value, either 00 or 111. Some processes (chosen by nature) are faulty; their ‚Äúintention‚Äù is to try to prevent agreement among the remaining processes. Each non-Byzantine process must decide 00 or 111. An execution of a protocol PùëÉP is successful for weak Byzantine agreement if the following two conditions hold:

  1. I.

    (Agreement:) All the non-Byzantine processes decide on the same value in {0,1}01\{0,1\}.

  2. II.

    (Weak Nontriviality:) If all processes are non-Byzantine and all processes have the same initial value iùëñi, then all the processes must decide iùëñi.

  • ¬†¬†¬†Proposition¬†¬†1.

    If max‚Å°{2,k+t}<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëòùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°\max\{2,k+t\}<n\leq 3k+3t, all 2nsuperscript2ùëõ2^{n} input values are equally likely, and PùëÉP is a (possibly randomized) protocol with finite expected running time, then there exists a protocol P‚Ä≤superscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P^{\prime} and a set TùëáT of players with |T|‚â§k+tùëáùëòùë°|T|\leq k+t such that an execution of (PN‚àíT,PT‚Ä≤)subscriptùëÉùëÅùëásubscriptsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤ùëá(P_{N-T},P^{\prime}_{T}) is unsuccessful for the weak Byzantine agreement problem with nonzero probability.

  • ¬†¬†¬†Theorem¬†¬†3.
