A.2 Proof of Theorem¬†4

  • ¬†¬†¬†Theorem¬†¬†4.

    If 2‚Äãk+2‚Äãt<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò2ùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°2k+2t<n\leq 3k+3t, then there exists a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, an œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, and a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma, for which there does not exist a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT game that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma such that œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma.

Proof.

Consider a variant of the game described in the proof of Theorem¬†3:

Game ŒìŒì\Gamma has 2‚Äãk+2‚Äãt<n‚â§3‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò2ùë°ùëõ3ùëò3ùë°2k+2t<n\leq 3k+3t players.   • ‚Ä¢

    If there exists a set RùëÖR of at least n‚àí(k+t)ùëõùëòùë°n-(k+t) players that choose G such that

    • ‚Äì

      all players in RùëÖR either commonly output 0 or commonly output 1; and

    • ‚Äì

      if all players in RùëÖR have initial value iùëñi then the common output of RùëÖR is iùëñi;

    then we call this a good outcome, the utility is 111 for players that choose G and output the same value as the players in RùëÖR, and the utility is 0 for all other players.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Otherwise we have a bad outcome, and the utility is 00 for players that choose G and 161616 for players that choose B.

Consider the same mediator as in Theorem¬†3, except that rather than sending punish if fewer than n‚àí(k+t)ùëõùëòùë°n-(k+t) values are sent, the mediator simply sends 0. A.4 Proof of Theorem¬†6

  • ¬†¬†¬†Theorem¬†¬†6.

    If 2‚Äãk+2‚Äãt<n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùëò2ùë°ùëõ2ùëò3ùë°2k+2t<n\leq 2k+3t and t‚â•1ùë°1t\geq 1, there exists a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, an œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma, and a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma, such that there does not exist a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT extension of ŒìŒì\Gamma which is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma.

The proof uses a reduction to a generalization of the Byzantine agreement problem called the (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-Detect/Agree¬†problem, which, as we said, is closely related to the problem of broadcast with extended consistency introduced by Fitzi¬†et al.¬†[FHHW03]. We have two parameters, kùëòk and tùë°t. Each process has some initial value, either 00 or 111. There are at most k+tùëòùë°k+t Byzantine processes. Each non-Byzantine process must decide 0,1,010,1, or detect. An execution is successful for Detect/Agree if the following three conditions all hold (the first two of which are slight variants of the corresponding conditions in weak Byzantine agreement):

  1. I.

    (Agreement:) If there are tùë°t or fewer Byzantine processes, then all non-Byzantine processes decide on the same value, and it is a value in {0,1}01\{0,1\}.

  2. II.

    (Nontriviality:) If all non-Byzantine processes have the same initial value vùë£v and no non-Byzantine process decides detect, then all the non-Byzantine processes must decide vùë£v.

  3. III.

    (Detection validity:) If there are more than tùë°t Byzantine processes, then either all the non-Byzantine processes decide detect, or all non-Byzantine processes decide on the same value in {0,1}01\{0,1\}.

Note that if k=0ùëò0k=0, then clause III is vacuous, so the (0,t)0ùë°(0,t)-Detect/Agree¬†problem is equivalent to Byzantine agreement with tùë°t faulty processes [LSP82]. Note that the non-triviality condition for Byzantine agreement requires all processes to decide vùë£v if they all had initial value vùë£v, even if there are some faulty processes. Thus, it is a more stringent requirement than the weak nontriviality condition of weak Byzantine agreement.

The following argument, from which it follows that there does not exist a protocol for the (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-Detect/Agree¬†problem if n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ2ùëò3ùë°n\leq 2k+3t, is based on a variant of the argument used for Proposition¬†1. If T‚äÜNùëáùëÅT\subseteq N, let 1‚ÜíT‚Äã0‚ÜíN‚àíTsubscript‚Üí1ùëásubscript‚Üí0ùëÅùëá\vec{1}_{T}\vec{0}_{N-T} denote the input vector where the players in TùëáT get an input of 1 and the players in N‚àíTùëÅùëáN-T get an input of 0.

Proposition 4.

If max‚Å°{2,t}<n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãt2ùë°ùëõ2ùëò3ùë°\max\{2,t\}<n\leq 2k+3t and t‚â•1ùë°1t\geq 1, then for all joint protocols PùëÉP, there exist six scenarios S0,‚Ä¶,S5subscriptùëÜ0‚Ä¶subscriptùëÜ5S_{0},\ldots,S_{5}, six protocols PhjsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëó‚ÑéP^{j}_{h}, for j=0,1ùëó01j=0,1, h=0,1,2‚Ñé012h=0,1,2, and a partition of the players into three nonempty sets B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0}, B1subscriptùêµ1B_{1}, and B2subscriptùêµ2B_{2} such that |B0|‚â§tsubscriptùêµ0ùë°|B_{0}|\leq t, |B1|‚â§k+tsubscriptùêµ1ùëòùë°|B_{1}|\leq k+t, and |B2|‚â§k+tsubscriptùêµ2ùëòùë°|B_{2}|\leq k+t, and

  • ‚Ä¢

    in scenario S0subscriptùëÜ0S_{0}, the input vector is 0‚Üí‚Üí0\vec{0}, in S1subscriptùëÜ1S_{1}, it is 0‚ÜíB1‚à™B2‚Äã1‚ÜíB0subscript‚Üí0subscriptùêµ1subscriptùêµ2subscript‚Üí1subscriptùêµ0\vec{0}_{B_{1}\cup B_{2}}\vec{1}_{B_{0}}; and in S2subscriptùëÜ2S_{2}, it is 0‚ÜíB2‚Äã1‚ÜíB0‚à™B1subscript‚Üí0subscriptùêµ2subscript‚Üí1subscriptùêµ0subscriptùêµ1\vec{0}_{B_{2}}\vec{1}_{B_{0}\cup B_{1}}; in S3+hsubscriptùëÜ3‚ÑéS_{3+h}, the input vector is the complement of the input vector in ShsubscriptùëÜ‚ÑéS_{h}, for h=0,1,2‚Ñé012h=0,1,2 (that is, if process iùëñi has input ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell in ShsubscriptùëÜ‚ÑéS_{h}, it has input 1‚àí‚Ñì1‚Ñì1-\ell in S3+hsubscriptùëÜ3‚ÑéS_{3+h}); for all protocols PjsuperscriptùëÉùëóP^{j}, for j=0,1ùëó01j=0,1;

Proof.

The following is a generalization of the well-known result that Byzantine agreement (which, as we have observed, is just the (0,t)0ùë°(0,t)-Detect/Agree¬†problem) cannot be solved if n‚â§3‚Äãtùëõ3ùë°n\leq 3t.

Proposition 5.

If n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ2ùëò3ùë°n\leq 2k+3t and t‚â•1ùë°1t\geq 1, then there is no protocol that solves the (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-Detect/Agree¬†problem. Proof.

Suppose that n‚â§2‚Äãk+3‚Äãtùëõ2ùëò3ùë°n\leq 2k+3t and that PùëÉP solves the (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-Detect/Agree¬†problem. Consider the six scenarios from Proposition¬†4. Since t‚â•1ùë°1t\geq 1, each of B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0}, B1subscriptùêµ1B_{1}, and B2subscriptùêµ2B_{2} is nonempty. In scenario S0subscriptùëÜ0S_{0}, all the correct processes must decide on 0, by the nontriviality condition. By Proposition¬†4, the processes in B2subscriptùêµ2B_{2} cannot distinguish S0subscriptùëÜ0S_{0} from S1subscriptùëÜ1S_{1} and are correct in both, therefore the correct processes must decide 0 in S1subscriptùëÜ1S_{1}. But in S3subscriptùëÜ3S_{3} the nonfaulty processes must decide 1. This proves the first part of the claim.

Now suppose that each of 0‚Üí‚Üí0\vec{0}, 1‚ÜíB0‚Äã0‚ÜíB1‚à™B2subscript‚Üí1subscriptùêµ0subscript‚Üí0subscriptùêµ1subscriptùêµ2\vec{1}_{B_{0}}\vec{0}_{B_{1}\cup B_{2}}, 1‚ÜíB0‚à™B1‚Äã0‚ÜíB2subscript‚Üí1subscriptùêµ0subscriptùêµ1subscript‚Üí0subscriptùêµ2\vec{1}_{B_{0}\cup B_{1}}\vec{0}_{B_{2}}, and 1‚Üí‚Üí1\vec{1} have probability 1/4141/4. Again, consider the scenarios S0,‚Ä¶,S3subscriptùëÜ0‚Ä¶subscriptùëÜ3S_{0},\ldots,S_{3}. We claim that, for some j‚àà{0,1,2,3}ùëó0123j\in\{0,1,2,3\}, if the faulty processes use the strategies prescribed for scenario SjsubscriptùëÜùëóS_{j}, then conditional on the input vector being that of scenario SjsubscriptùëÜùëóS_{j}, the probability that an execution is unsuccessful for (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-Detect/Agree is at least 1/5151/5. We prove by induction on jùëój that either the claim holds for some scenario SjsubscriptùëÜùëóS_{j} with 0‚â§j‚â§30ùëó30\leq j\leq 3 or the probability that each correct process in scenario SjsubscriptùëÜùëóS_{j} decides 0 is greater than 1‚àí(j+1)/51ùëó151-(j+1)/5. The inductive step is similar, and left to the reader. We complete the proof by observing that in S3subscriptùëÜ3S_{3}, if the claim does not hold, then all the processes must decide 0 with probability at least 1/5151/5. But in S3subscriptùëÜ3S_{3}, all processes are correct and have initial value 1. Thus, again the probability of an unsuccessful execution is at least 1/5151/5. Since each relevant input vector has probability 1/4141/4, the probability of an unsuccessful execution is at least 1/201201/20. ‚àé

A.5 Proof of Theorem¬†7

To prove Theorem¬†7, we start with the case that n=2ùëõ2n=2, k=1ùëò1k=1, and t=0ùë°0t=0. The ideas for this proof actually go back to Shamir, Rivest, and Adleman [SRA81]; a similar result is also proved by Heller [Hel05]. However, these earlier proofs assume that in the cheap-talk protocol, the players first exchange messages and then, after the message exchange, make their decision (perhaps using some randomization). That is, they are implicitly assuming that when the cheap-talk phase of the strategy has ended, it is common knowledge that it has ended (although when it ends may depend on some random choices). While this is a reasonable assumption if we have a bounded cheap-talk protocol, our possibility results involve cheap-talk games with no a priori upper bound on running time. We do not want to assume that the players receive a signal of some sort to indicate that the message exchange portion of the cheap-talk has ended. Our lower bound proof does not make this assumption. We can, of course, find a round such bùëèb that with high probability. This solves part of the problem. However, the earlier proofs also took advantage of the fact that players decide simultaneously, after the cheap-talk phase ends. Since we do not make this assumption, our proof requires somewhat more delicate techniques than the proofs in the earlier papers.

Proposition 6.

If n=2ùëõ2n=2, then there exist a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, a mediator game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} extending ŒìŒì\Gamma, a Nash equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}, and a punishment strategy œÅùúå\rho with respect to œÉùúé\sigma such that there is no strategy œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} that is an œµ‚Äì‚Äã(1,0)œµ‚Äì10\mbox{$\epsilon$--}(1,0)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma.

Proof.

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma be the game described in the left table of Figure¬†2, where player 1 is Alice and player 2 is Bob, Alice can choose between actions UùëàU and Dùê∑D, and Bob can choose between LùêøL and RùëÖR. The players all have a single type in this game, so we do not describe the types. The boxes in the left table describe the utilities of Alice and Bob for each action profile. The right table describes a correlated equilibrium of this game, giving the probabilities that each action profile is played.

Consider the mediator game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} extending Œì,Œì\Gamma, where the mediator recommends the correlated equilibrium described in the table on the right of Figure¬†2 (that is, the mediator recommends choosing an action profile with the probability described in the table, and recommends that each player play his/her component of the action profile). Let œÉùúé\sigma be the strategy profile of following the mediator‚Äôs recommendation. It is easy to see that œÉùúé\sigma is a Nash equilibrium of the mediator game; moreover, (D,R)ùê∑ùëÖ(D,R) is a punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma. Also, note that the requirement of a broadcast channel trivially holds if n=2ùëõ2n=2.

Suppose, by way of contradiction, that œÉ‚Ä≤=(œÉ1‚Ä≤,œÉ2‚Ä≤)superscriptùúé‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúé1‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúé2‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime}=(\sigma_{1}^{\prime},\sigma_{2}^{\prime}) is a (1/10)110(1/10)-Nash equilibrium that implements œÉùúé\sigma in a CT extension ŒìctsubscriptŒìct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} of ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}. Since œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} implements œÉùúé\sigma, it must be the case that, with probability 1, an execution of œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} terminates. Hence, there must be some round bùëèb such that, with probability at least 1‚àí1Œ≤2,11superscriptùõΩ21-\frac{1}{\beta^{2}}, œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} has terminated (with both players choosing an action in the underlying game) by the end of round bùëèb. (We determine Œ≤ùõΩ\beta shortly.)

The execution of œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} is completely determined by the random choices made by the players. Let ‚Ñõisubscript‚Ñõùëñ\mathcal{R}_{i} denote the set of possible sequences of random choices by player iùëñi. (For example, if player iùëñi randomizes by tossing coins, then r‚àà‚Ñõiùëüsubscript‚Ñõùëñr\in\mathcal{R}_{i} can be taken to be a countable sequence of coin tosses.) For ease of exposition, we assume that iùëñi makes a random choice at every time step (if the move at some time step in the cheap-talk game is deterministic, then iùëñi can ignore the random choice at that time step). If rùëür is a sequence of random choices, we use r‚Ñìsuperscriptùëü‚Ñìr^{\ell} to denote the subsequence of rùëür consisting of the random choices made in the first ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell steps. Since œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} implements œÉùúé\sigma, with probability 1, both players choose an action in the underlying game in an execution of œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime}. (That is, while it is possible that there are infinite executions of œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} where some party does not choose an action, they occur with probability 0.) Let ‚Ñõ=‚Ñõ1√ó‚Ñõ2‚Ñõsubscript‚Ñõ1subscript‚Ñõ2\mathcal{R}=\mathcal{R}_{1}\times\mathcal{R}_{2}. Note that the probability on the random sequences in ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R} determines the probability of outcomes according to œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime}.

Suppose that rùëür is a finite random sequence of length ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell for player iùëñi. We take Pr‚Å°(r)=Pr‚Å°({s‚àà‚Ñõi:s‚Ñì=r})PrùëüPrconditional-setùë†subscript‚Ñõùëñsuperscriptùë†‚Ñìùëü\Pr(r)=\Pr(\{s\in\mathcal{R}_{i}:s^{\ell}=r\}). The random sequences determine the message history and the actions. Given random sequences r1subscriptùëü1r_{1} and r2subscriptùëü2r_{2} of length ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell, let H‚Äã(r1,r2)ùêªsubscriptùëü1subscriptùëü2H(r_{1},r_{2}) be the pair of message histories (h1,h2)subscript‚Ñé1subscript‚Ñé2(h_{1},h_{2}) determined by (r1,r2)subscriptùëü1subscriptùëü2(r_{1},r_{2}), and let A‚Äã(r1,r2)=(a1,a2)ùê¥subscriptùëü1subscriptùëü2subscriptùëé1subscriptùëé2A(r_{1},r_{2})=(a_{1},a_{2}) be the action profile chosen as a result of (r1,r2)subscriptùëü1subscriptùëü2(r_{1},r_{2}) (where we take aisubscriptùëéùëña_{i} to be ‚ä•bottom\bot if player iùëñi has not yet taken an action); in this case, we write Ai‚Äã(r1,r2)=aisubscriptùê¥ùëñsubscriptùëü1subscriptùëü2subscriptùëéùëñA_{i}(r_{1},r_{2})=a_{i}, for i=1,2ùëñ12i=1,2.

A pair of histories (h1,h2)subscript‚Ñé1subscript‚Ñé2(h_{1},h_{2}) of equal length is deterministic for player iùëñi if it is not the case that both of player iùëñi‚Äôs actions have positive probability, conditional on the message history being (h1,h2)subscript‚Ñé1subscript‚Ñé2(h_{1},h_{2}). If the players play the message sent by the mediator (and do not play the optional value), then they get expected payoff 8/3838/3.

We now show that this strategy is (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t) robust. For tùë°t-immunity, note that the tùë°t players cannot take over all of Ai‚à™Bsubscriptùê¥ùëñùêµA_{i}\cup B for i=1ùëñ1i=1 or i=2ùëñ2i=2 (since both of these sets have cardinality k+tùëòùë°k+t), so they cannot take advantage of sending the optional element of {U,D,L,R}ùëàùê∑ùêøùëÖ\{U,D,L,R\}. If any of the tùë°t players are shown to be unreliable, it is easy to see that this cannot hurt the other players, since there will not be more than tùë°t unreliable players. If the reliable players do not send values that pass checks (a), (b), (c), and (d) above, then each player gets 8/3838/3, which is the expected payoff of playing the recommended strategy. Finally, if a large enough subset of the tùë°t players manage to guess the check vectors and send values that satisfy (a), (b), (c), and (d) above, because they do not know any of the secrets, they are effectively making a random change to the output, so the expected payoff is still 8/3838/3.

For (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t) robustness, note that a set of k+tùëòùë°k+t that consist of all of Ai‚à™Bsubscriptùê¥ùëñùêµA_{i}\cup B for i=1ùëñ1i=1 or i=2ùëñ2i=2 can change the output by all playing the same optional value, but they cannot improve their payoff this way, since we have a correlated equilibrium in the 2-player game. If all k+tùëòùë°k+t players are in group A1‚à™Bsubscriptùê¥1ùêµA_{1}\cup B, and their value is UùëàU, they can try to change the outcome to (D,L)ùê∑ùêø(D,L) by all playing Dùê∑D and guessing shares and check values in the hope of changing them to the (D,L)ùê∑ùêø(D,L) outcome. But if they are caught, they will all get 0. Since |F|‚â•6ùêπ6|F|\geq 6, the probability of getting caught is greater than 1/4141/4, so they do not gain by deviating in this way.

Note that if n>k+2‚Äãtùëõùëò2ùë°n>k+2t, then if n‚àí(k+t)ùëõùëòùë°n-(k+t) players deliberately do not play the values sent them by the mediator, then this is a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma, since n‚àí(k+t)>tùëõùëòùë°ùë°n-(k+t)>t.

Finally, the same argument as in the 2-player game shows that, by taking over either A1‚à™Bsubscriptùê¥1ùêµA_{1}\cup B or A2‚à™Bsubscriptùê¥2ùêµA_{2}\cup B, a set of size k+tùëòùë°k+t can improve their outcome by deviating. ‚àé

A.6 Proof of Theorem¬†8

  • ¬†¬†¬†Theorem¬†¬†8.

    If max‚Å°(2,k+t)<n‚â§k+3‚Äãt2ùëòùë°ùëõùëò3ùë°\max(2,k+t)<n\leq k+3t, then there is a game ŒìŒì\Gamma, a strong (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium œÉùúé\sigma of a game ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dùëëd that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma for which there does not exist a strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT game that extends ŒìŒì\Gamma such that œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon‚Äì(k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust implementation of œÉùúé\sigma even if players are computationally bounded and we assume cryptography.

Proof.

We consider a relaxation of Byzantine agreement that we call the (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-partial broadcast problem. There are nùëõn processes and process 111 is designated as leader. The leader has an initial value 0 or 1. Each process must decide on a value in {0,1,pass}01pass\{0,1,{\textsc{pass}}\}. An execution of a protocol PùëÉP is successful for (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-partial broadcast if the following two conditions hold:

  1. I.

    (Agreement): If there are tùë°t or fewer Byzantine processes and the leader is non-Byzantine then all non-Byzantine processes decide on the leader‚Äôs value.

  2. II.

    (No disagreement): If there are k+tùëòùë°k+t or fewer Byzantine processes, then there do not exist two non-Byzantine processes such that one decides 0 and the other decides 1.

Note that if the leader is faulty, it is acceptable that some non-Byzantine processes decide on a common value v‚àà{0,1}ùë£01v\in\{0,1\} and all other non-Byzantine processes decide pass. Observe that the (0,t)0ùë°(0,t)-partial broadcast problem is a relaxation of the well-known Byzantine generals problem [LSP82]. We provide probabilistic lower bounds for this problem, which also imply known probabilistic lower bounds for the Byzantine generals problem.

We now construct a game that captures the (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-partial broadcast problem. Given kùëòk and tùë°t, consider the following game ŒìŒì\Gamma with nùëõn players.     Utility for player i‚â†1ùëñ1i\neq 1:

Consider a mediator that receives a value from the broadcaster and sends this value to all players. Consider the truthful strategy œÉùúé\sigma in the mediator game: players tell the mediator the truth, and the mediator reports the secret. The strategy profile œÉùúé\sigma gives both players utility 1 for all utility function uM,Œ¥superscriptùë¢ùëÄùõøu^{M,\delta}. Truthfulness is easily seen to be a 1-robust strategy in the mediator game (i.e., a Nash equilibrium). If a player iùëñi lies and i¬Ø¬Øùëñ\bar{i} tells the truth, then with probability 6/7676/7, iùëñi will be caught. In this case, iùëñi will definitely play the wrong value. Moreover, it is easy to see that, if Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0 and iùëñi chooses a value at random, then if player i¬Ø¬Øùëñ\bar{i} chooses the same value, his expected utility is 1/7+6/7‚Äã(1‚àíŒ¥)=1‚àí6‚ÄãŒ¥/717671ùõø16ùõø71/7+6/7(1-\delta)=1-6\delta/7; if player i¬Ø¬Øùëñ\bar{i} chooses a different value, then his expected utility is M/7+(‚àíM+2‚àí2‚ÄãŒ¥)/7+(1‚àíŒ¥)‚Äã(5/7)=1‚àíŒ¥ùëÄ7ùëÄ22ùõø71ùõø571ùõøM/7+(-M+2-2\delta)/7+(1-\delta)(5/7)=1-\delta; it follows that player i¬Ø¬Øùëñ\bar{i}‚Äôs expected utility is at most 1‚àí6‚ÄãŒ¥/716ùõø71-6\delta/7. For part (a), fix œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0 and bùëèb. Suppose, by way of contradiction, that there exists such a cheap-talk strategy œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}. The key idea is to consider the expected probability that a player will be able to guess the correct answer at any round, assuming that both players use œÉctsubscriptùúéct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}. With no information, the probability that iùëñi guesses the right answer is 1/7171/7 and all values are equally likely. When the strategy terminates, the probability must be 1 (because we assume that both players will know the right answer at the end if they follow the recommended strategy). (Proof: Consider a round b‚Ä≤superscriptùëè‚Ä≤b^{\prime} such that player 1‚Äôs expected probability of guessing the right answer increases by at least 3/7‚Äãb37ùëè3/7b. For the general argument, we do the proof of part (a) here; the modifications needed to deal with part (b) are straightforward. Consider a k+t+1ùëòùë°1k+t+1 out of nùëõn secret sharing game, where the initial shares are ‚Äúsigned‚Äù using check vectors. Specifically, for each share f‚Äã(i)ùëìùëñf(i) and for each player j‚ààN‚àñiùëóùëÅùëñj\in N\setminus{i}, player iùëñi is given a uniformly random value yi‚Äãjsubscriptùë¶ùëñùëóy_{ij} in FùêπF and player jùëój is given a uniformly random value bi‚Äãjsubscriptùëèùëñùëób_{ij} in F‚àñ{0}ùêπ0F\setminus\{0\} and a value ci‚Äãjsubscriptùëêùëñùëóc_{ij} such that f‚Äã(i)+yi‚Äãj‚Äãbi‚Äãj=ci‚Äãjùëìùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñùëósubscriptùëèùëñùëósubscriptùëêùëñùëóf(i)+y_{ij}b_{ij}=c_{ij}. In the underlying game, players can either choose a value in the field (intuitively, their best guess as to the secret) or play detect. The utility functions are defined as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    if at least n‚àítùëõùë°n-t players play detect, then all players playing detect get 1, and all others get 0;

  • ‚Ä¢

    if fewer than n‚àítùëõùë°n-t players play detect and at least n‚àí(k+t)ùëõùëòùë°n-(k+t) but fewer than n‚àítùëõùë°n-t players play the secret, then the players playing the secret get MùëÄM and the other players get ‚àíM+2‚àí2‚ÄãŒ¥ùëÄ22ùõø-M+2-2\delta

  • ‚Ä¢

    if fewer than n‚àítùëõùë°n-t players play detect and either n‚àítùëõùë°n-t or more players or fewer than n‚àí(k+t)ùëõùëòùë°n-(k+t) players play the secret, then the players playing the secret get 1, and the remaining players get 1‚àíŒ¥1ùõø1-\delta.

In the mediator game, each player is supposed to send the mediator his type (share, signatures, and verifications). The mediator checks that all the shares sent pass the checks. Note that each share can be subjected to nùëõn checks, one for each player. A share is reliable if it passes at least n‚àítùëõùë°n-t checks. If there are not at least n‚àítùëõùë°n-t reliable shares, but a unique polynomial fùëìf can be interpolated through the shares that are sent, then the mediator sends a random value that is not f‚Äã(0)ùëì0f(0) to all the players; otherwise, the mediator chooses a value in FùêπF at random and sends it to all the players. If there are at least n‚àítùëõùë°n-t reliable shares, the mediator checks if a unique polynomial of degree k+tùëòùë°k+t can be interpolated through the shares. If so, the mediator sends the secret to all the players; if not, the mediator sends detect to all the players. Let œÉùúé\sigma be the strategy for the players where they truthfully tell the mediator their type, and play what the mediator sends.

We claim that playing 1 is a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to œÉùúé\sigma if Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0 and n>k+2‚Äãtùëõùëò2ùë°n>k+2t, and that œÉùúé\sigma is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium. The argument that playing 1 is a (k+t)ùëòùë°(k+t)-punishment strategy is essentially identical to the argument for the 2-player game. However, note that if n‚â§k+2‚Äãtùëõùëò2ùë°n\leq k+2t, then t‚â•n‚àí(k+t)ùë°ùëõùëòùë°t\geq n-(k+t). If at most tùë°t players play 1, this is not a punishment strategy since the remaining n‚àítùëõùë°n-t players can play detect and guarantee themselves a payoff of 1.

To show that œÉùúé\sigma is a (k,t)ùëòùë°(k,t)-robust equilibrium, we first show it is tùë°t-immune. Either the mediator can interpolate a unique polynomial fùëìf of degree k+tùëòùë°k+t through the reliable shares or not. In the former case, the good players will learn the secret; in the latter case, the good players will play detect. In either case, their payoff is 1. Thus, œÉùúé\sigma is tùë°t-immune.

Suppose that this mediator strategy can be implemented using cheap talk. We claim that, as in the proof of Theorem¬†7, we can use the implementation to give a cheap-talk implementation in the 2-player game.
